title: AB 1673
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for use as a weapon that expels a projectile through a barrel by the force of an explosion or combustion. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections that define the term "firearm" and its exceptions. It encompasses devices designed to expel projectiles through explosion or combustion, including rockets and launchers. Certain provisions exclude unloaded antique firearms from this definition. The Penal Code defines "firearm" and its exceptions, excluding unloaded antique firearms in specific provisions. It also clarifies that in certain sections, a firearm does not include a destructive device or has the same meaning as in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted to functional weapons. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" as a device that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. The definition includes various sections of the code, specifying what is considered a firearm and what is not. The Penal Code specifies that a "firearm" excludes unloaded antique firearms in certain sections, such as Sections 26030, 16730, 16550, 16960, 17310, 25250, 26350, 26400, 26500-26588, 26700-26915, 27510-27585, 29010-29150, and 25135. Additionally, in Sections 34005 and 34010, a "firearm" does not include a destructive device, while in Sections 17280 and 24680, it aligns with the definition in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150 and Section 25135, "firearm" excludes destructive devices. In Sections 17280 and 24680, "firearm" aligns with the definition in Section 922 of Title 18 of the United States Code. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted to functional condition. "Frame" and "receiver" refer to parts of a firearm housing essential components and designed exclusively for use in a functional weapon. Sections 27510, 27530, 27540, 27545, 27555 to 27585, 29010 to 29150, 25135, and 29180 define the term "firearm" in various contexts. Sections 29010 to 29150 also encompass unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into functional components. (g) In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted to functional components. (h) "Frame" and "receiver" refer to parts of a firearm housing the hammer, bolt, or firing mechanism, designed exclusively for use in a functional weapon. Section 1.1 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, contingent on the enactment of Senate Bill 894 and certain conditions being met. Section 1.2 of the bill incorporates amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code proposed by this bill, Senate Bill 1407, and Assembly Bill 857, with specific conditions for its enactment. Section 1.3 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code from multiple bills, with specific conditions for its enactment. It will only be effective if certain criteria are met regarding the enactment of other related bills. No reimbursement required by this act under the California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
